diagrams.description: Materials engineering has ancient roots with the Stone Age, Bronze Age, and Iron Age marking major material developments in human civilization. The Industrial Revolution (1700s-1800s) brought steel production advances (Bessemer process 1856) and understanding of material properties. The early 1900s introduced stainless steel (1913), aluminum alloys, and early polymer development (Bakelite 1907). The 1940s-50s witnessed titanium production, synthetic polymers proliferation (nylon, polyester), and semiconductor materials for electronics. The 1960s brought composite materials development for aerospace and the beginning of materials science as a distinct discipline. The 1970s introduced advanced ceramics, high-strength steels, and engineering polymers. The 1980s-90s saw nanomaterials emergence, shape memory alloys, and high-temperature superconductors discovery. The 2000s advanced with carbon nanotubes, graphene isolation (2004), and metamaterials development. The 2010s-2020s continue with 2D materials, self-healing materials, programmable materials, additive manufacturing materials, biomimetic materials, and sustainable material alternatives becoming research frontiers.

timeline
    title The History of Materials Engineering
    section Prehistoric Eras
        Stone Age : Stone tools
        Bronze Age : Bronze tools and weapons
        Iron Age : Iron tools and weapons
    section 19th Century: Industrial Revolution
        1855 : Bessemer process for steel production
        1886 : Hall-HÃ©roult process for aluminum production
    section Early 20th Century: The Age of Polymers
        1907 : Bakelite, the first synthetic plastic
        1930s : Nylon is invented
    section Mid-20th Century: The Silicon Age
        1947 : The transistor is invented
        1950s : Development of silicon-based semiconductors
    section Late 20th & 21st Century: Advanced Materials
        1960s : Development of composite materials
        1980s : High-temperature superconductors
        1991 : Carbon nanotubes are discovered
        2004 : Graphene is isolated
        2010s : Rise of metamaterials and 3D printing
